ReST says that the relationship between the returned representation and the 
underlying model is entirely arbitrary.
So what is truly goofy is that, with ReST, I don't even know what the 
result of a GET means without out of band documentation! 
Pre/Post-conditions are really irrelevant to solving this problem.

Here is another way to think about this from an OO/MVC perspective:

* ReST: the web server should hide the data model and implement the viewer 
and controller itself.
(Pre/post-conditions are irrelevant to ReST because they are already 
enforced by the server-based controller.)

* MoST the web server should expose the data model (aka class instance or 
data+content-type/schema) and the client should implement the viewer and 
controller.
(Pre/post-conditions are irrelevant to MoST because they are covered in the 
content-type/schema definition.)

As a programmer, I would much rather code against a model with clearly 
articulated interface (specified by a content-type/schema) than I would 
against arbitrary ReST UI components.  Effectively ReST means writing 
screen-scraping applications.  In advocating MoST, I am claiming that 
screen-scraping is silly.

>>>>>> "Alex" == Alex Jacobson <alex@...> writes:
>
>     Alex> I think it is goofy that ReST means that I can have
>     Alex> absolutely no idea what the effect of PUT or POST actually
>     Alex> is without an extended out of band conversation with the web
>     Alex> server operator.
>
> That's true for every routine and function you call in this world. The
> solution to this (not widely used yet, too many people seem to love C)
> is the notion of pre- and postcondition:
>
> 1. If the client fullfills its part of the obligation, i.e. meeting
>    all the conditions stated in the precondition,
>
> 2. then the server fullfills its part of the obligation, i.e. meeting
>    all the conditions stated in the postcondition.
>
> Everything beyond that is of no concern to the client.
>
>
> Explicit pre- and postconditions are missing from REST, but that it is
> all you need. If the precondition states that you can PUT, you can. If
> the postcondition states that the result of the PUT is that a GET
> returns the putted resource, than that's all there is.
>
> If you seek an understanding of how different resouces work together
> and how to accomplish certain tasks (booking a meeting with different
> participans for example), that has and will always be part of the
> documentation. That's just part of the architecture. UI don't see any
> metamodel solving that problem.
